questions.questionText: Radioactivity is a process that can be predicted precisely for each individual nucleus.
questions.solution: False. Radioactivity is inherently random at the level of individual nuclei; it is impossible to predict exactly when a specific nucleus will decay.
questions.hint: Consider the unpredictability of nuclear decay events at the atomic level.

questions.questionText: The Becquerel (Bq) is the SI unit of radioactive activity, defined as one disintegration per second.
questions.solution: True. The Becquerel (Bq) is the SI unit for measuring radioactive activity and is defined as one disintegration per second.
questions.hint: Recall the definition of the Becquerel in terms of disintegrations per second.

conceptStatistics.concept: Becquerel (Bq) and Its Relationship to dps

questions.questionText: One Curie (Ci) is equivalent to one Becquerel (Bq).
questions.solution: False. One Curie is a much larger unit than one Becquerel; specifically, 1 Ci equals 3.7 × 10^10 Bq.
questions.hint: Consider the numerical relationship between Ci and Bq units.

questions.questionText: The decay probability per unit time (λ) is a constant for a given radioactive isotope.
questions.solution: True. The decay constant (λ) is a characteristic property of each radioactive isotope, representing the probability of decay per unit time.
questions.hint: Think about the definition of the decay constant in radioactive decay.

questions.questionText: In exponential decay, the number of undecayed nuclei decreases linearly over time.
questions.solution: False. In exponential decay, the number of undecayed nuclei decreases exponentially over time, not linearly.
questions.hint: Consider the mathematical nature of the decay equation.

questions.questionText: Half-life is the time required for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay.
questions.solution: True. By definition, half-life (t₁/₂) is the time it takes for half of the nuclei in a radioactive sample to undergo decay.
questions.hint: Recall the definition of half-life in radioactive decay.

conceptStatistics.concept: Definition and Derivation from Decay Constant (λ)

questions.questionText: The mean life (τ) of a radioactive isotope is longer than its half-life.
questions.solution: True. The mean life τ is related to the half-life t₁/₂ by τ = t₁/₂ / ln(2), so it is approximately 1.44 times longer than the half-life.
questions.hint: Consider the mathematical relationship between mean life and half-life.

questions.questionText: The decay constant (λ) varies over time for a given radioactive isotope.
questions.solution: False. The decay constant (λ) is a fixed value for a given isotope and does not change over time.
questions.hint: Think about whether λ is affected by external conditions or time.

questions.questionText: The fraction of nuclei that decay during a time interval depends on the total number of nuclei present initially.
questions.solution: False. In exponential decay, the fraction of nuclei that decay over a given time interval is independent of the initial number of nuclei.
questions.hint: Consider the properties of fractional decay in radioactive processes.

conceptStatistics.concept: Independence from Initial Nuclei Count or Time

questions.questionText: In parallel decay reactions, multiple decay paths occur independently from the same parent nucleus.
questions.solution: True. In parallel decay, a parent nucleus can decay via different modes independently, each characterized by its own decay constant.
questions.hint: Think about how multiple decay modes can coexist for a single isotope.

questions.questionText: In a series decay reaction, the daughter nucleus is always stable.
questions.solution: False. In series decay reactions, the daughter nucleus may itself be radioactive and undergo further decay until a stable nucleus is formed.
questions.hint: Consider the possibility of successive decays in a decay series.

questions.questionText: Carbon dating relies on the decay of carbon-14 to estimate the age of organic materials.
questions.solution: True. Carbon dating measures the remaining amount of carbon-14 in organic materials to estimate their age based on its known half-life.
questions.hint: Think about how carbon-14 decay is used in dating archaeological samples.

conceptStatistics.concept: Estimating Age of Organic Material via ¹⁴C Decay

questions.questionText: The exponential decay formula can be used to determine the activity of a radioactive sample at any given time.
questions.solution: True. The exponential decay equation relates the activity of a sample to time, allowing calculation of activity at any point.
questions.hint: Recall how the exponential decay formula relates activity and time.

questions.questionText: After two half-lives, one-fourth of the original radioactive nuclei remain undecayed.
questions.solution: True. After each half-life, the number of undecayed nuclei halves. Therefore, after two half-lives, (1/2) × (1/2) = 1/4 remain.
questions.hint: Calculate the remaining fraction after two successive halvings.

questions.questionText: Carbon dating can be used to accurately date inorganic materials like rocks and metals.
questions.solution: False. Carbon dating is effective for dating organic materials that contain carbon-14, not inorganic substances like rocks and metals.
questions.hint: Consider the types of materials that contain carbon-14.

questions.questionText: What is the SI unit of radioactive activity, defined as one disintegration per second?
questions.solution: The SI unit of radioactive activity is the Becquerel (Bq), which equals one disintegration per second.
questions.hint: It's named after the scientist who discovered radioactivity.

conceptStatistics.concept: Becquerel (Bq) and Its Relationship to dps

questions.questionText: Which unit of radioactive activity is equal to 3.7 × 10¹⁰ Becquerels?
questions.solution: The Curie (Ci) is equal to 3.7 × 10¹⁰ Becquerels and is a non-SI unit of radioactivity.
questions.hint: It's named after a pioneering female scientist in radioactivity.

questions.questionText: What is the term for the constant representing the decay probability per unit time for a radioactive isotope?
questions.solution: The decay constant, denoted by the Greek letter lambda (λ), represents the decay probability per unit time.
questions.hint: It's symbolized by the Greek letter λ.

questions.questionText: What type of mathematical function describes the decay of radioactive nuclei over time?
questions.solution: The decay of radioactive nuclei over time is described by an exponential function.
questions.hint: It's a function where the rate of change is proportional to the quantity itself.

questions.questionText: What term describes the time required for half of the radioactive nuclei in a sample to decay?
questions.solution: This term is known as the half-life of the radioactive isotope.
questions.hint: It's commonly denoted as t₁/₂.

conceptStatistics.concept: Definition and Derivation from Decay Constant (λ)

questions.questionText: What term is used for the average lifetime of a radioactive nucleus before it decays?
questions.solution: The term is mean life, representing the average time before decay.
questions.hint: It's calculated as the reciprocal of the decay constant λ.

conceptStatistics.concept: Definition and Derivation from Exponential Decay

questions.questionText: Radioactive decay is inherently __________, meaning it cannot be predicted for individual nuclei.
questions.solution: Radioactive decay is inherently random.
questions.hint: It's the opposite of deterministic.

questions.questionText: The introduction of the decay constant (λ) leads to the establishment of the __________ law.
questions.solution: The decay constant leads to the establishment of the radioactivity law.
questions.hint: It's the fundamental law governing radioactive decay.

questions.questionText: A plot of the natural logarithm of the number of undecayed nuclei versus time yields a __________ line.
questions.solution: It yields a straight line.
questions.hint: In such a graph, the relationship is linear.

questions.questionText: Mean life (τ) is calculated as the reciprocal of the __________ constant.
questions.solution: Mean life τ is calculated as τ = 1/λ, where λ is the decay constant.
questions.hint: It's symbolized by λ.

questions.questionText: In a series decay reaction, nuclei undergo decay in a __________ sequence of reactions.
questions.solution: In a series decay reaction, nuclei decay in a sequential manner.
questions.hint: It's the opposite of parallel.

questions.questionText: Carbon dating relies on the radioactive decay of carbon-14 to __________.
questions.solution: Carbon dating relies on carbon-14 to date organic materials.
questions.hint: It's the process of determining the age of an object.

conceptStatistics.concept: Estimating Age of Organic Material via ¹⁴C Decay

questions.questionText: Marie Curie is known for her pioneering work in the field of __________.
questions.solution: Marie Curie is renowned for her work in radioactivity.
questions.hint: She coined the term for the phenomenon involving spontaneous emission of particles.

questions.questionText: The fundamental principle of radioactive decay states that decay probability is proportional to __________.
questions.solution: Decay probability is proportional to time interval dt.
questions.hint: It's the infinitesimally small time over which decay is considered.

conceptStatistics.concept: Fundamental Principle: Decay Probability ∝ λ dt

questions.questionText: Radioactive generation at a constant rate involves both decay and constant __________ of nuclei.
questions.solution: It involves constant production or generation of nuclei.
questions.hint: It's the process of creating new nuclei.

questions.questionText: In carbon dating, the decay law is used to calculate the elapsed __________ since the death of the organism.
questions.solution: The decay law is used to calculate the elapsed time.
questions.hint: It's a measure of duration.

conceptStatistics.concept: Elapsed Time Calculation Based on Remaining ¹⁴C

questions.questionText: Fractional decay is independent of the initial number of nuclei and the elapsed __________.
questions.solution: Fractional decay is independent of the elapsed time.
questions.hint: It's the variable represented by t in decay equations.

conceptStatistics.concept: Independence from Initial Nuclei Count or Time

questions.questionText: In parallel decay reactions, the equivalent half-life is derived from the individual __________ constants.
questions.solution: It's derived from the individual decay constants.
questions.hint: These constants represent the decay probabilities.

questions.questionText: In exponential decay, the rate of decay is proportional to the __________ number of undecayed nuclei.
questions.solution: The rate of decay is proportional to the current number of undecayed nuclei.
questions.hint: It's the number of nuclei present at a given time.

questions.questionText: Carbon dating is widely used in archaeology to estimate the age of __________ materials.
questions.solution: Carbon dating estimates the age of organic materials.
questions.hint: These materials come from living organisms.

questions.questionText: Who is credited with the discovery of radioactivity?
questions.solution: Henri Becquerel is credited with the discovery of radioactivity in 1896 when he observed that uranium salts emitted rays that could fog photographic plates.
questions.hint: He was a French physicist who shared the 1903 Nobel Prize in Physics.

questions.questionText: Which of the following best describes the nature of radioactive decay?
questions.solution: Radioactive decay is a random process at the level of single atoms, meaning it's impossible to predict exactly when a particular nucleus will decay.
questions.hint: Consider the predictability of decay events for individual nuclei.
options: A) Deterministic and predictable for each nucleus
B) Random and unpredictable for each nucleus
C) Influenced by external environmental conditions

questions.questionText: Which unit is defined as one disintegration per second?
questions.solution: The Becquerel (Bq) is the SI unit of radioactive activity, defined as one disintegration per second.
questions.hint: It's the SI unit named after the discoverer of radioactivity.

conceptStatistics.concept: Becquerel (Bq) and Its Relationship to dps

questions.questionText: One Curie (Ci) is equivalent to how many Becquerels (Bq)?
questions.solution: One Curie is equal to 3.7 × 10^10 Becquerels.
questions.hint: Recall the conversion factor between Curie and Becquerel units.

questions.questionText: The decay constant (λ) represents which of the following?
questions.solution: The decay constant (λ) represents the probability per unit time that a nucleus will decay.
questions.hint: Think about what λ indicates in the context of radioactive decay.
options: B) Decay probability per unit time

questions.questionText: Which mathematical expression represents the number of undecayed nuclei N at time t?
questions.solution: The exponential decay law is N = N₀ e^(−λt), where N₀ is the initial number of nuclei.
questions.hint: It's derived from the decay probability and involves an exponential function.

questions.questionText: On a graph of radioactive decay, what shape does the decay curve of N versus time t take?
questions.solution: The decay curve of N versus t is an exponential decay curve, which decreases rapidly at first and then levels off.
questions.hint: Consider the graphical representation of an exponential function.
options: B) Straight line with negative slope

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fraction of nuclei that decay over a given time interval?
questions.solution: In exponential decay, the fraction of nuclei that decay over a given time interval is independent of the initial number of nuclei.
questions.hint: Think about how fractional decay relates to the initial quantity.
options: A) It depends on the initial number of nuclei
B) It depends on the absolute time elapsed
C) It is independent of the initial number of nuclei
D) It increases exponentially with time

conceptStatistics.concept: Independence from Initial Nuclei Count or Time

questions.questionText: How is the half-life (t₁/₂) of a radioactive isotope related to its decay constant (λ)?
questions.solution: The half-life is related to the decay constant by t₁/₂ = ln(2)/λ.
questions.hint: Recall the mathematical relationship involving natural logarithm of 2.

conceptStatistics.concept: Definition and Derivation from Decay Constant (λ)

questions.questionText: After how many half-lives will the fraction of undecayed nuclei be approximately 12.5%?
questions.solution: After three half-lives, the fraction remaining is (1/2)^3 = 12.5%.
questions.hint: Calculate (1/2) raised to the number of half-lives.

questions.questionText: Which expression correctly relates mean life (τ) to the decay constant (λ)?
questions.solution: Mean life τ is the reciprocal of the decay constant, τ = 1/λ.
questions.hint: Mean life is the average lifetime of a nucleus before decay.

questions.questionText: In parallel decay reactions, the overall decay constant is:
questions.solution: For parallel decay, the overall decay constant is the sum of the individual decay constants: λ_total = λ₁ + λ₂ + ...
questions.hint: Think about how multiple independent decay paths contribute to the total decay rate.
options: A) Equal to the smallest individual λ
B) Equal to the largest individual λ
C) The sum of the individual λ values
D) The product of the individual λ values

questions.questionText: When a radioactive substance is generated at a constant rate while simultaneously decaying, its activity reaches a steady state when:
questions.solution: The activity reaches a steady state when the rate of production equals the rate of decay.
questions.hint: Consider the conditions for dynamic equilibrium in decay and generation.
options: C) Decay rate equals generation rate
D) Decay rate exceeds generation rate

questions.questionText: In a series decay reaction, which of the following describes the relationship between the parent and daughter activities at equilibrium?
questions.solution: At equilibrium, the activity of the daughter equals the activity of the parent if the half-life of the parent is much longer than that of the daughter.
questions.hint: Consider secular equilibrium conditions in decay series.
options: A) Parent activity is greater than daughter activity
B) Parent activity is less than daughter activity
C) Parent and daughter activities are equal

conceptStatistics.concept: Total Decay Rate Calculation in Series

questions.questionText: Carbon dating is based on the decay of which isotope?
questions.solution: Carbon dating relies on the decay of carbon-14 (¹⁴C) to estimate the age of organic materials.
questions.hint: It's a radioactive isotope of carbon with 8 neutrons.

conceptStatistics.concept: Basis of Carbon Dating and Radioactive Decay

questions.questionText: The half-life of carbon-14 is approximately 5730 years. If a sample shows 25% of its original carbon-14 content, how old is the sample?
questions.solution: 25% remaining means two half-lives have passed: 2 × 5730 = 11,460 years.
questions.hint: Calculate the number of half-lives corresponding to 25% remaining.

conceptStatistics.concept: Elapsed Time Calculation Based on Remaining ¹⁴C

questions.questionText: Which of the following factors can affect the accuracy of carbon dating?
questions.solution: Contamination of the sample with modern carbon can affect the accuracy of carbon dating.
questions.hint: Think about external factors that could alter the carbon-14 content.
options: A) Half-life of carbon-14 changing over time
B) Fluctuations in Earth's gravitational field
C) Sample contamination with newer carbon
D) The initial amount of carbon-12 in the sample

questions.questionText: Which of the following correctly compares mean life (τ) and half-life (t₁/₂)?
questions.solution: Mean life τ is related to half-life t₁/₂ by τ = t₁/₂ / ln(2).
questions.hint: Recall the mathematical relationship involving natural logarithms.

questions.questionText: Which scientist's work is most associated with the statistical nature of radioactive decay?
questions.solution: Ernest Rutherford contributed significantly to the understanding of the statistical nature of radioactive decay.
questions.hint: He is known as the father of nuclear physics.

questions.questionText: In a decay series, if the half-life of the daughter isotope is much longer than that of the parent, what happens to the daughter isotope's quantity over time?
questions.solution: The daughter isotope accumulates over time because it decays much more slowly than it is being produced.
questions.hint: Consider the rates of decay for parent and daughter isotopes.
options: A) It reaches a constant amount
